The Cabinet had before them a letter,circulated by direction of the Prime Minister,from the Chairman of the Conservative andUnionist Party ashing for instructions In regardto a conference between representatives of theUnionist Liberal and Labour Parties on thesubject of the broadcasting of controversy,which had been suggested by the British Broad-easting Corporation (Paper C.P.-158 (28)).Prom this Memorandum it transpired thatthe following scheme had been proposed on behalfof the British Broadcasting Corporation:-(a) For an initial period of threeweeks each of the three parties should be given an opportunityof arranging for an uncensoredenunciation of Party policy,lasting for half an hour, theParties following each other in successive weeks:(b) After this period of three weeks the system should be put upon afortnightly basis, in the rotaof a Government spokesman to eachOpposition spokesman:(c) That the system should continue until the dissolution of Parlia-ment, subject to special arrange-ments being made by agreementbetween the Parties during the periods when the House of commons would not be in session:(d) That during the General Electionthe general principle should bethat each Party should have equalfacilities, arrangements beingdecided upon later.Difficulties, however, had been found in some quarters In accepting these proposals, with theresult that the conference already referred tohad been proposed. In the event of a conference the main issue to be joined was likely to be onthe question whether the system should be based on the rota of a Government spokesman to eachOpposition spokesman or whether the three parties should follow each other in rotation.The Cabinet agreed -That the Prime Minister should instruct the representatives ofthe Conservative and unionist party at the Conference to stand firm In support of the original proposals of the british broadcasting Corporation, whereby the Government of the day wouldhave an opportunity of replying to each of the other political parties; that is to say that the spokesman for the Government shouldhave equal rights with the spokesman of each of the opposition parties a NAVAL OON-STRUCTXONPROGRAM IE .The Type ofCruiser for1928-29 .(previous reference:Cabinet 64(27), Con-clusion 1.)*T) 42. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the First Lord of the Admiralty (Paper C.P.-156 (28)) in regard to the question of whetherthe two Cruisers approved for the Naval Con-struction Programme for 1928--29 should beClass "A" or Class WB*, a question which hadbeen reserved by the Cabinet at the meeting referred to in the margin in order that all the factors bearing on the situation might be ^nownbefore the Cruisers are laid down.In view of the fact that the dropping ofcertain Cruisers from the British ConstructionProgrammes of the last two years had not resultedin any change in the actual authorised pro-grammes of other Powers, and that all the cruisers of the American Programme would be of $Wthe Class "A" type, the First Lord recommendedthat the Eritish Cruisers should be of the "A"type and requested the authority of the Cabinetto proceed accordingly.The Cabinet were reminded that, since the circulation of the Memorandum by the First Lordof the Admiralty, information had been receivedfroir Washington (Sir E. Howard, No.155, of May15th) on the authority of "The Times" Correspond-ent there, to the effect that the American naval construction Bill was lihely to be held over until the next Session in December.The Cabinet were given to understand thatthe Chancellor of the Exchequer (absent throughprobablvindisposition) was/in agreement with the Admiralty'proposal, but tbe Cabinet felt that the formal 45-6ii decision on the matter should be subject to hisconcurrence. On this condition the cabinet agreed To approve the proposal of theFirst lord of the Admiralty thatthe two Cruisers to be laid downin 1928-29 should be of the Class"A" type.The Secretary was instructed to obtainthe decision of the Chancellor ofthe Exchequer at the earliestpossible moment. 3. The Cahinet had before then? a Memorandumby the President of the Board of Trade (paper c.P.-152 (28)) stating that he had receivedfrom the Iron and Steel Wire ManufacturersAssociation an application for an Inquiry underthe Safeguarding of Industries Procedure inregard to Iron and Steel Wire of all kinds .He recalled that a similar application, made in1925 as part of a general application by theIron and Steel industry, had been rejected onthe ground that the Government's decision inregard to the application of the steel industry as a whole would apply also to sectional appli-cations. A similar attitude had been adopted towards a separate application made in February,1926. The President of the Board of Tradetherefore expressed In his Memorandum the pre-sumption that he should inform the applicantsthat the decision of 1926 still stands, viz.:-"The Government have given carefulconsideration to the arguments advanced, but they are of opinionthat the same consideration whichdebarred them from referring thelarger application to a Committeewould in fact operate in regard tosectional applications".The Cabinet approved the proposal of the President of the Board ofTrade in Paper CP.-152 (28) asset forth above. The Cabinet had before their the following documents in regard to the Indian High CourtsBillY-A Memorandum by the Secretary ofState for India, covering the bill and an explanatory Memorandum(Paper E.A.-15 (28)):A further Memorandum by theSecretary of State for India(Paper H.A.-19 "(28)):The recommendation of the Committeeof Home Affairs (.K.A. 7th Conclusions(28)) .In accordance with the recommendation ofthe Committee of Home Affairs, the Cabinet agreedTo authorise the introduction forthwith in the House of lords of the Indian High Courts Billin the form of the draft annexed to Paper H.A.-15 (28)).The Prime Minister said he would holdout no hopes that this Bill would get throughthe House of Commons in the present Sessionof Parliament.S2 SPE3D LIMITS .(previous reference:Cabinet 51(27), Oon-conclusion 9 &Appendix.)5. The Secretary of State for Scotlandreminded the Cabinet that the questions beforethe Imperial Conference on Wireless Telegraphyand Cables were to form the subject of a debate in the House of Commons on Monday next, andthe subject was discussed, brieflycThe Cabinet agreed (a) That the Secretary of State forScotland, as Chairman of theImperial Conference, would haveno alternative but to inform theHouse of Commons that the Conferencebeing still in session he could.not make any report as to what wasproposedP and that he did. not anticipate that the Conference wouldcomolete its labours in much lessthan a month. He should remind the House of Commons that otherGovernments were concerned, which necessitated reticence on his part.Parliament, however, would have tobe consulted before any actioninvolving: an" considerable changein the present situation could betaken.(b) The secretary of State for Scotland was asked, to confer with theParliamentary Secretary to theTreasury in regard to the intervention of private Members as a counterpoiseto proposals which might be madein favour of nationalisation andother proposals contrary to thepolicy of the Government.8o ,,rKAL trans-t.oosed enquiry into o7. The Prime Minister brought to the noticeof the Cabinet a question on which he had been approached by the Minister of Transport,relating to the proposed enquiry into transport,and the Minister of Transport was introduced intothe Cabinet to discuss the matter.The Cabinet were reminded that on the28th February, 1928, the Prime Minister, in answer to the Leader of the Opposition, saidthat the Government had in contemplation to institute without undue delay an investigation into the need for better regulation of road traffic, and the possibility of greater co-ordination of our internal means of transport.After some discussion, the Cabinet agreed(a) That while no announcement onthe subject should be made untiltowards the end of July, theMinister of Transport should,have authority to make preliminaryarrangements for the setting upof a Royal Commission in theautumn, including, subject to thePrime Minister1s concurrence, the selection of a suitable chairman and confidential consultation withindividuals likely to be concernedin the work of the Commission.(b) That the Secretary of State forScotland should have authority,if he thought desirable in the debate arranged in the House ofCommons on the following day, torefer to coastwise traffic as oneof the subjects which might usefully be enquired into by the proposedinvestigation into the co-ordinationof our internal means of transport. 8. The Home Secretary consulted his colleagues in regard to the attitude he should adopt in debate the same evening on a Motion for the adjournment of the House of Commons. This Debatehad been arranged duFinec Question time that day in conseauence of certain allegations made as tothe methods of investigation employed by thePollce in an inquiry on behalf of the Directorof Prosecutions in order to enable the latter to decide whether proceedings should be taken against certain nolice officers.After hearing from the Home Secretary allthe particulars of the case which he hadup tothat moment been able to obtain as the result ofinquiries to which he had devoted most of the afternoon, the Cabinet agreed with the HomeSecretary:-(a) That Sir William Joynson-Kicksshould be authorised, after makinga venr full statement to the Houseof Commons, to announce the inten-tion of the Government to hold an inquiry into the whole matter:(b) That if at any time he mightdesire to confer with some of hiscolleagues in regard to the consti-tution of the Inauiry or othermatters of detail,- the LordChancellor and the secretary ofState for India should hold them-selves at the disposal of the HomeSecretary. Sir John Simon, Chairman of the IndianStatutory Commission, attended the Cabinet forthe purpose of giving his impressions of theresults of the Commission's first visit toIndia. As his remarks to the Cabinet were notreported, Sir John Simon undertook, at therequest of the Secretary of State for India, tfurnish a Memorandum for circulation to theCabinet.The Secretary of State for Indiaplaced on record the obligation which he andhis colleagues felt to Sir John Simon forthe self"Sacrifice he had made in undertakingthis enormously important task. LordBirkenhead also expressed the desire of theCabinet to assist the Royal Commission inits difficult task In any way which mightbe possible.On the conclusion of Sir John Simon'sstatement, the Prime Minister thanked himwarmly for giving the Cabinet the benefitof his impressions on his return from India.Whitehall Gardens, S.W.I.18th May, 1928.
